In the Horn of Africa, Ethiopia is facing crises on several fronts.
In the capital, most of the leaders of the political opposition are in jail after deadly riots.
And the United Nations says both Ethiopia and Eritrea are massing troops along their disputed border.
The tensions are raising questions about Ethiopia's future.
NPR's Jason Beaubien reports.
In 1998, Ethiopia and Eritrea went to war over a tiny border town called Badme.
Now Badme isn't even its own town.
Officially, the village is part of a municipality that's more than an hour's drive by 4x4 to the south.
On Sunday afternoon, goats wander along the single dusty street that runs through Badme.
Ethiopian soldiers drink beer in several small, makeshift bars.
In 2002, an international border commission ruled that Badme lies in Eritrea, but now the Ethiopian army is digging trenches around this remote outpost.
Fifty-year-old Kiros Beverchekos(ph), who fled the village during the fighting in 1998, says Badme will never be part of Eritrea.
(Foreign language spoken)
`This is our land,' he says.
`Even if the border commission rules that Badme is part of Eritrea, we will never give it up.
We will fight forever.'
In October, Eritrea banned UN flights over the border, dramatically limiting the ability of peacekeepers to patrol the area.
In addition to the threat of war, political riots in early November swept across Ethiopia.
The riots and the ensuing government crackdown left more than 40 people dead, some 10,000 people in prison, and the future of democracy in Ethiopia in doubt.
Most of the leaders of the political opposition have been arrested and charged with treason.
Beyene Petros, one of the few opposition leaders who isn't in jail, says Ethiopia's going through its most difficult period in more than a decade.
Well, you can see this is a country, you know, that can absorb a lot of abuse.
And that's--I think of the thing we know is misery.
So we are used to living under such excesses.
Beyene, who leads the United Ethiopian Democratic Forces, says Ethiopia started to open up socially and politically in the run-up to the May elections.
There were political debates and frank criticism of the ruling party.
But then when the early poll results appeared to show the opposition making significant gains, all that openness came to an end.
The voting places were shut down, election monitors were sent home and federal police took to the streets.
In June, when the ruling party announced that it had won the election, riots broke out in the capital, Addis Ababa.
After the November riots, several independent newspapers were shut down and their editors imprisoned.
Now state-run media runs a fairly steady stream of propaganda labeling the political opposition as violent criminals.
Evidence indicate that the Coalition for Unity and Democracy, CUD, has deployed these rioters in order to accomplish its mission.
This mission indeed is a reflection of CUD dissidents to rebel the constitutional order through street violence.
Leaders of the CUD say they're opposed to violence and that the recent riots broke about because armed police tried to drive protesters off the streets.
Beyene Petros with the UEDF says there's very little room now for opposition politicians to push their agendas.
He says this is not the time to openly challenge the ruling party.
So perhaps what is at stake here is this question of multiparty democratization that was talked a lot about may be on hold for some time to come.
In response, Britain and the European Union have threatened to cut some development aid to Ethiopia.
Prior to the May elections, things had been going relatively well for the country.
After decades of autocratic rule under Emperor Haile Selassie and Marxist dictator Mengistu Haile Mariam, there was political stability and a move towards multiparty politics.
Economic growth was increasing, international assistance of $1.8 billion a year had been pouring into the country to improve literacy rates, increase agricultural production and fight disease.
Bjorn Ljungqvist, the head of UNICEF in Ethiopia, says the last border war with Eritrea, from 1998 to 2000, severely disrupted UNICEF's development work.
Over the last two years, he says, his organization has regained momentum and increased its operations almost fourfold.
Ljungqvist says the threat of a new war with Eritrea and the political instability in Addis Ababa could derail UNICEF's operations again.
